title: Figurative Language — Simile and Metaphor
description: Students learn to identify and use similes (comparisons using like or as) and metaphors (direct comparisons without like or as). They find examples in literature and write their own.
instructions:
1. Ask: 'What does it mean when someone says he ran like the wind? Did he actually become wind? No — it is a comparison!'
2. Introduce SIMILE: a comparison using 'like' or 'as.' 'She was as brave as a lion.' 'The stars twinkled like diamonds.'
3. Introduce METAPHOR: a comparison WITHOUT like or as. 'He is a rock.' 'Life is a journey.' The thing IS the other thing.
4. Compare: simile says something is LIKE something else. Metaphor says it IS something else.
5. Find examples in read-aloud books from previous weeks.
6. Simile and metaphor sorting activity: classify 15 sentences.
7. Students write 5 similes and 5 metaphors in their journals.
materials_needed: Sorting cards with similes and metaphors

slides.heading: Figurative Language
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of a book, and it's introducing us to a super fun way writers make their stories exciting! We're going to learn about "figurative language," which just means using words in a special, creative way, and we'll focus on two kinds: similes and metaphors.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 15 sentence cards: 7-8 similes and 7-8 metaphors for sorting. Mark simile and metaphor examples in previously read books.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our writing adventure today! We've got a whiteboard and markers to write down our ideas, some special cards for a sorting game, our writing journals and pencils for creating our own sentences, and examples from books we've already read. Make sure you have all these things ready to go!

slides.text: 'When a writer says The warrior was as fierce as a lion, did the warrior literally become a lion? No! The writer is making a COMPARISON to help us picture how fierce the warrior was. This special comparison is called a SIMILE. Similes use the words LIKE or AS. Listen for those signal words!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the magic starts! Imagine someone says "He was as fierce as a lion." Did he actually grow a mane and roar? Nope! The writer is just using "as" to compare how brave he was to a lion, helping us imagine it better. That's a simile – a comparison that uses "like" or "as" to paint a picture.

slides.text: 'Now what if the writer says The warrior WAS a lion in battle? No like or as — just IS. This is a METAPHOR. The writer says the warrior IS a lion to create an even stronger image. Both similes and metaphors paint pictures in the reader's mind, but metaphors are more direct and powerful.' Write examples of each on the board.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, what if the writer said, "He WAS a lion in battle"? See how there's no "like" or "as"? This is a metaphor, and it's like saying the warrior *became* a lion for that moment to show how strong he was. It’s a more direct way to compare things and make your writing super powerful.

slides.text: 'Let us find the clue: does it have LIKE or AS? Then it is a SIMILE. Is it a direct comparison without those words? Then it is a METAPHOR. The classroom was a zoo (metaphor). The classroom was like a zoo (simile). The meaning is similar, but the form is different.' Practice with 5 examples together.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like our clue-finder! To know if it's a simile or a metaphor, we just need to look for two special words: "like" or "as." If you see them, it's a simile! If the sentence makes a strong comparison but skips those words, then it’s a metaphor. We'll practice figuring them out together!

slides.prompt: Sort the 15 sentence cards into similes and metaphors. Then write 5 original similes and 5 original metaphors in your journal. Try to make them vivid and creative! Example simile: 'The Aegean Sea sparkled like a field of sapphires.' Example metaphor: 'Athens was the brain of Greece.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for the fun sorting challenge! You'll get a pile of sentence cards, and your job is to read each one and decide if it's a simile (using "like" or "as") or a metaphor (a direct comparison). After you sort them, you get to be the writer and create five of your own similes and five of your own metaphors in your journal – make them super creative!

slides.text: Similes and metaphors are tools that make writing come alive. They paint pictures in the reader's mind. Similes compare using like or as. Metaphors compare directly. Look for them in everything you read this week — once you know what they are, you will see them everywhere!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student distinguish between similes and metaphors and write original examples of each?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we did it! We learned that similes and metaphors are like secret codes that writers use to make their stories pop and help us imagine amazing things. Remember, similes use "like" or "as," and metaphors say something *is* something else. Keep an eye out for them in all the books you read – they're everywhere!

parent_notes: Figurative language is a major reading comprehension skill and a powerful writing tool. Once children learn to recognize similes and metaphors, they find them everywhere — in books, songs, conversations, and advertisements. Encourage your child to collect favorites in a special section of their journal. Song lyrics are full of figurative language and make great practice material.

title: Measurement — Mass: Grams and Kilograms
description: Students learn to measure mass (how heavy something is) using metric units: grams and kilograms. They use a balance scale to weigh objects and understand the relationship 1 kg = 1,000 g.
instructions:
1. Distinguish mass from weight: mass is the amount of matter in an object (does not change); weight is the pull of gravity (changes on the moon). For everyday purposes, we use them similarly.
2. Units: the gram (g) is the basic unit. A paperclip weighs about 1 gram.
3. A kilogram (kg) = 1,000 grams. A liter of water weighs 1 kg. A textbook weighs about 1 kg.
4. Demonstrate the balance scale: place object on one side, known weights on the other. When balanced, the mass is equal.
5. Students weigh 8-10 objects: estimate first, then weigh.
6. Classify objects: would you measure this in grams or kilograms?
7. Practice conversion: 3 kg = 3,000 g; 5,500 g = 5.5 kg.

slides.heading: Measurement
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our title slide for today's lesson! We're going to become super-sleuths and learn all about "mass," which is just a fancy word for how much "stuff" is inside an object, or how heavy it feels. We'll be using special units called grams and kilograms to measure it.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the balance scale. Gather 8-10 objects of varying masses. Have known weights organized by size. Prepare a recording chart.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, it's time to get our tools ready for our mass investigation! We need a balance scale, which is like a seesaw for tiny weights, and a set of gram weights that look like little metal blocks. We also need the things we're going to weigh, like toys or classroom supplies, and a chart to write down what we find. Grab those with a grown-up and let's get started!

slides.text: 'We measured LENGTH in centimeters and meters. Now we measure MASS — how much matter is in an object, or how heavy it is. The basic unit is the GRAM. How heavy is 1 gram? About the same as a paperclip!' Hold up a paperclip. 'Very light! For heavier things, we use KILOGRAMS: 1 kilogram = 1,000 grams.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Last time we talked about measuring how long things are, right? Well, now we're going to measure how *heavy* things are, which scientists call "mass." We use grams for tiny things, like this paperclip you see here – it's super light! For bigger, heavier things, we use kilograms, and a kilogram is like having a thousand of those little grams all together.

slides.text: 'A kilogram is about as heavy as a liter bottle of water.' Hold one up. 'Or about as heavy as a thick textbook. YOUR body mass is measured in kilograms — most children your age have a mass of about 20-30 kg. An elephant is about 5,000 kg! A mouse is about 20 grams.'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, imagine a big bottle of water – that's about how heavy a kilogram feels. Or think about a thick book you might read; that’s also around one kilogram. Your own body has a mass measured in kilograms, but a tiny little mouse would only be measured in grams because it's so light!

slides.text: Demonstrate the balance scale: 'Place the object on one side. Add weights to the other side until the scale balances. Then add up the weights — that is the object's mass!' Weigh an apple together: add 100g, 50g, 20g, 10g... it balances at about 180g. 'The apple has a mass of about 180 grams.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's learn how to use this balance scale! You put the thing you want to weigh on one side, and then you carefully add these known weights to the other side, like building blocks, until the scale is perfectly level. When it's balanced, the total weight of those little blocks tells you exactly how heavy your object is, just like how this apple weighs about 180 grams.

slides.prompt: Weigh 8 objects: estimate the mass first, then use the balance scale to find the actual mass. Record in your chart. Then answer: Which is heavier, 2 kg or 1,500 g? Convert to the same unit to check! Solve: A bag of flour is 2 kg. You use 750 g. How much is left?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the scientist! Pick up one of your objects and guess if it's heavier than a paperclip (so, grams) or heavier than a bottle of water (so, kilograms). Then, use the balance scale to see how close your guess was and write it down. After you weigh a few things, we'll do some fun puzzles where you have to compare grams and kilograms, like figuring out how much flour is left in the bag.

slides.text: Mass tells us how much matter is in an object. We measure in grams (small objects) and kilograms (heavy objects). 1 kg = 1,000 g. A paperclip is about 1 g, a liter of water is about 1 kg. Conversion works just like length: multiply to go from kg to g, divide to go from g to kg.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student use a balance scale to measure mass and convert between grams and kilograms?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did an amazing job exploring mass today! You learned that grams are for lighter things, like a paperclip, and kilograms are for heavier things, like a bottle of water, and that 1,000 grams make up 1 kilogram. You're now a pro at using the balance scale to measure how much "stuff" is in objects, just like a real scientist!

parent_notes: A balance scale is ideal for teaching mass because it makes the concept concrete. If you do not have one, a kitchen scale works well too. Cooking is a perfect context for practicing mass measurement — recipes use grams frequently. Benchmarks are key: 1 gram = paperclip, 100 grams = apple (roughly), 1 kilogram = liter of water. The kg-to-g conversion follows the same pattern as km-to-m (x1000).

title: Ancient Greece — The Philosophers: Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle
description: Students learn about the three great Greek philosophers and their contributions to thinking and learning. They explore the Socratic method, Plato's Academy, and Aristotle's scientific observations.
instructions:
1. What is philosophy? Love of wisdom (philo = love, sophia = wisdom).
2. SOCRATES: asked questions instead of giving answers. The Socratic method: teaching by asking 'Why?' over and over. He believed 'The unexamined life is not worth living.'
3. PLATO: Socrates's student. Started the Academy (one of the first schools!). Wrote dialogues. Believed in ideal forms.
4. ARISTOTLE: Plato's student. Studied EVERYTHING: science, politics, logic, animals, ethics. Tutor to Alexander the Great.
5. These three are like a chain: Socrates taught Plato, Plato taught Aristotle.
6. Practice the Socratic method: ask 'Why?' 5 times about a simple statement.
7. Students write a brief biography of one philosopher.
materials_needed: Images or busts of Socrates, Plato, Aristotle

slides.heading: Ancient Greece
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our book about ancient Greece! It tells us we're going to learn about some super smart people called "The Great Philosophers" who lived a very, very long time ago. Isn't it exciting to explore history?

slides.setup_instructions: Print images of the three philosophers. Place them on the timeline. Have a simple biography reference available for each.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our adventure into ancient Greece! We've got pictures of Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle – our main guys – and a timeline to see when they lived. We'll also need some paper and pencils to write down what we learn, and maybe a whiteboard to share our ideas.

slides.text: 'Greece gave us something even more important than buildings or art — it gave us PHILOSOPHY: the love of wisdom. Philo means love, sophia means wisdom. Philosophers ask the biggest questions: What is truth? What is goodness? How should we live? Today we meet three of the greatest thinkers in history.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we learn what "philosophy" even means! It’s like a special kind of thinking that means "love of wisdom." These philosophers weren't just smart; they loved figuring out the biggest questions, like what's right and wrong, or how we should all live together.

slides.text: 'SOCRATES taught by asking questions. Instead of telling his students the answer, he would ask Why? over and over until they figured it out themselves. He said: The only true wisdom is knowing that you know nothing. He never wrote anything down! His student PLATO wrote down his ideas and started the ACADEMY — one of the first schools in history.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we meet Socrates, the first super-smart guy! He was really good at asking questions, especially "Why?" He believed that asking questions helps us learn more than just being told answers. His student, Plato, was so inspired that he started one of the very first schools ever!

slides.text: 'ARISTOTLE was Plato's best student, but he went even further. He studied EVERYTHING: animals, plants, stars, government, logic, poetry, weather. He was the first person to organize knowledge into categories. And he became the tutor of a young prince named Alexander — who would become Alexander the Great! Socrates taught Plato, Plato taught Aristotle — a chain of genius.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we meet Aristotle, who was Plato's student! Aristotle was curious about *everything* – from tiny bugs to how stars move. He was like a super scientist and organizer, and he even taught a famous prince named Alexander. It's like a super-teacher chain: Socrates taught Plato, and Plato taught Aristotle!

slides.prompt: First, practice the Socratic method: start with 'It is important to learn.' Ask 'Why?' Answer, then ask 'Why?' again. Keep going 5 times. Then choose one philosopher and write a short biography: when they lived, what they believed, what they are famous for, and why they matter today.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's activity time! First, we'll pretend to be Socrates by asking "Why?" five times about a simple idea, like "It's good to learn." Then, you get to pick one of the philosophers and write a little bit about their life and what made them so special. You've got this!

slides.text: Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle created the foundations of Western thought. Socrates taught us to question everything. Plato showed us the power of ideas. Aristotle showed us how to observe and organize knowledge. Their ideas, from 2,400 years ago, still shape how we think, learn, and govern today.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student name the three Greek philosophers, describe their key ideas, and explain the teacher-student chain?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we made it to the end! We learned about Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle – three amazing thinkers whose ideas still help us understand the world today. We learned how they asked questions, shared ideas, and studied everything around them, and how they even taught each other!

parent_notes: Philosophy for children is about teaching thinking skills. The Socratic method — asking 'Why?' repeatedly — is a powerful dinner table activity. Children love asking 'why?' anyway! The teacher-student chain (Socrates to Plato to Aristotle) is an easy mnemonic: S-P-A (SPA). Aristotle's broad interests connect to the Montessori philosophy of the interconnectedness of knowledge. Ask your child: 'What big questions would you like to answer?'

title: Europe — Countries, Capitals, and Major Features
description: Students explore the continent of Europe: its major countries, capital cities, mountain ranges, rivers, and the European Union. They compare Europe's size and diversity to other continents studied.
instructions:
1. Show Europe on the globe and world map. It shares a landmass with Asia (Eurasia).
2. Europe is the second-smallest continent but has many countries (~50!).
3. Major countries: France, Germany, Italy, Spain, United Kingdom, Greece, and others.
4. Major features: Alps mountains, Rhine River, Danube River, English Channel, Scandinavian Peninsula.
5. Briefly introduce the European Union (EU): a partnership of countries that cooperate economically.
6. Fun fact: many European countries are smaller than US states!
7. Students label a map of Europe with at least 10 countries, 5 capitals, and 3 physical features.

slides.heading: Europe
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our big adventure! It's showing us that we're going to be learning all about Europe, including all the different countries, their main cities called capitals, and cool things like mountains and rivers.

items: Political and physical maps of Europe
slides.setup_instructions: Print blank outline maps of Europe. Display both political and physical reference maps. Have the atlas available for students to look up countries and capitals.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool tools we'll need for our European journey! We've got maps that show the countries and mountains, a blank map to fill in, a globe to see where Europe is in the world, colored pencils to make it pretty, and an atlas which is like a big book of maps. Go grab all these things so we're ready to go!

slides.text: 'Today we zoom out from Greece to look at the whole continent of EUROPE! Find it on the globe. Europe is actually connected to Asia — together they form EURASIA. Europe is the second-smallest continent, but it has about 50 countries packed into it! That is a LOT of different cultures, languages, and traditions.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our first step in exploring Europe! We're going to find Europe on the globe, and you'll see it's sitting right next to Asia, like two giant puzzle pieces. Even though Europe is small, it's packed with tons of countries, which means lots of different people and fun traditions!

slides.text: 'Here are some major countries.' Point to each on the map. 'France — capital Paris, the Eiffel Tower! Germany — capital Berlin. Italy — shaped like a boot, capital Rome. Spain — capital Madrid. The United Kingdom — London. And of course Greece — Athens. Each of these countries has its own language, food, and culture.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to meet some of the stars of Europe! We'll point out big countries like France, Germany, Italy (look, it's shaped like a boot!), Spain, the United Kingdom, and our old friend Greece. Each one is like its own little world with its own special language and yummy food.

slides.text: 'Physical features: the ALPS are Europe's highest mountains, running through France, Switzerland, Italy, and Austria. The RHINE and DANUBE are two great rivers. The ENGLISH CHANNEL separates Britain from France. And many European countries work together in the EUROPEAN UNION — they share a currency called the euro and cooperate on trade and laws.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us some of Europe's amazing natural wonders and a special club! The Alps are super tall mountains, and the Rhine and Danube are really long rivers. We'll also learn about the English Channel, which is like a big watery ditch, and the European Union, where countries work together like a team.

slides.prompt: On your blank map of Europe: (1) Color and label at least 10 countries. (2) Mark and label 5 capital cities with stars. (3) Label the Alps, Rhine River, Danube River, Mediterranean Sea, and Atlantic Ocean. (4) Draw a small symbol for each country's famous landmark if you know one!
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to become a Europe expert! You'll color in at least ten countries on your map, then put little stars on five capital cities, and label those awesome mountains and rivers. If you remember any cool buildings or statues from those countries, you can even draw them in!

slides.text: Europe may be small, but it is incredibly diverse — 50 countries, dozens of languages, and centuries of history packed into a continent smaller than some individual countries! We have already studied one European civilization in depth: Greece. In a few weeks, we will study Rome, another European powerhouse that changed the world.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student locate and name at least 10 European countries, 5 capitals, and major physical features?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You've learned that even though Europe is small, it's bursting with so many countries and cool places. Remember how we talked about Greece and how it's part of Europe? We'll even learn about ancient Rome later, another super important European place.

parent_notes: Europe geography connects directly to the history being studied. Consider using puzzle maps (Montessori-style) if available. The sheer number of countries makes Europe interesting but challenging. Focus on the major countries first and expand gradually. Food is a great connector: French crepes, Italian pasta, Spanish paella, British fish and chips, German pretzels. Plan a European food night!

title: Read Aloud — Greek Myth: Athena and Arachne
description: A read-aloud of the myth of Athena and Arachne, exploring themes of pride, talent, and the dangers of boasting. Students connect to the invertebrate unit (spiders/arachnids).
instructions:
1. Connect to science: 'Remember arachnids? Where does that word come from? Today we find out!'
2. Set context: Arachne was a mortal woman who wove the most beautiful tapestries.
3. Read the myth: Arachne boasted she was better than Athena. They had a weaving contest.
4. Arachne's tapestry was perfect — but it insulted the gods. Athena destroyed it and turned Arachne into a spider.
5. Discuss: Was Arachne talented? Yes! Was she wise? No — her pride angered a goddess.
6. Etymology: Arachne's name gives us 'arachnid' — the scientific name for spiders!
7. Students write about the theme and draw Arachne weaving.
materials_needed: Greek mythology book with Athena and Arachne

slides.heading: Read Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover page of our story today! It tells us we're going to read a myth about two characters named Athena and Arachne. A myth is a special kind of old story that often explains how things came to be or teaches us a lesson.

slides.setup_instructions: Select an age-appropriate version of the Athena and Arachne myth. Preview for discussion points.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us what we'll need for our story time and activity. We have a book with the myth, a journal for writing and drawing, and some colored pencils and regular pencils. You'll need to grab these things so you're ready for our adventure into the story!

slides.text: 'Remember when we studied arachnids — spiders? I promised you would find out where that word comes from. Today's myth explains it! It is the story of a woman named ARACHNE who was the greatest weaver in all of Greece. But she made a terrible mistake...'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is super important because it connects our story to what we learned in science! Remember those creepy crawly spiders we studied? The word "arachnid" for spiders actually comes from the name of the character in our story today, Arachne! This myth is going to tell us exactly why that is.

slides.text: Read the myth aloud. Pause at key moments: 'Arachne says she can weave better than Athena — the goddess of crafts! Would you dare challenge a goddess?' Build to the weaving contest and its dramatic conclusion.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for the exciting part – listening to the story! As I read, imagine Arachne working her loom, making amazing pictures with thread. Listen carefully to what she says about her weaving, especially when she talks about challenging a goddess – that's a big deal!

slides.text: After reading: 'Was Arachne talented? Absolutely — her weaving was perfect! But was she wise? She boasted and insulted the gods. This is hubris again — like Icarus. And now you know: spiders are called ARACHNIDS because of this myth. Arachne was turned into a spider, doomed to weave forever!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide helps us think about the story after we've heard it. We'll talk about how super talented Arachne was, but also how her pride got her into big trouble, just like the character Icarus we learned about before. And the coolest part is remembering that her name is why we call spiders "arachnids"!

slides.prompt: In your reading journal: (1) Draw Arachne at her loom, weaving her beautiful tapestry. (2) Write the lesson/moral of this myth. (3) Answer: How does this myth connect to our science lessons about arachnids? (4) Compare Arachne's hubris to Icarus's hubris — how are they similar?
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to show off what you learned with this activity! In your journal, you'll draw a picture of Arachne weaving her masterpiece, and then write down the main lesson from the story. You'll also write about how this ancient myth is connected to our science lessons about spiders and compare Arachne's mistake to Icarus's.

slides.text: Greek myths often warn against hubris — believing you are better than the gods. Arachne had extraordinary talent, but her pride was her downfall. Her name lives on in science: arachnid. This is cross-curricular learning at its best: mythology, science, and language all connected!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student retell the Arachne myth, explain the word origin of 'arachnid,' and identify the theme of hubris?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned a fantastic Greek myth about Arachne, and now you know that her name is the reason we call spiders "arachnids" – how amazing is that?! You discovered how being super talented is great, but letting pride get too big can cause problems, just like in other myths we've read.

parent_notes: This myth brilliantly connects to the science unit on arachnids. The word etymology (arachnid from Arachne) demonstrates how mythology lives on in our language. The theme of hubris recurs in Greek mythology — compare to Icarus from last week. Discuss with your child: is there a difference between being proud of your work and being boastful? How can we celebrate talent without hubris?

title: Figurative Language — Personification
description: Students learn about personification: giving human qualities to non-human things. They identify personification in literature and everyday language and write sentences using this technique.
instructions:
1. Review simile and metaphor from Day 1.
2. Introduce PERSONIFICATION: giving human qualities to animals, objects, or ideas.
3. Examples: 'The wind whispered through the trees.' (Wind cannot whisper.) 'The sun smiled down on us.' (Sun cannot smile.) 'Time flies.' (Time has no wings.)
4. Discuss: personification makes writing more vivid and emotional. It helps us connect to non-human things.
5. Find personification in familiar texts and songs.
6. Game: take an object and give it 3 human qualities (the angry volcano, the lazy river, the dancing leaves).
7. Students write 8 personification sentences and illustrate their favorite one.
materials_needed: Object cards for the personification game

slides.heading: Figurative Language
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover page of our adventure! It tells us we're going to learn about something super cool called "Figurative Language," and the special part we're focusing on today is called "Personification." It’s like a secret code for making writing more exciting!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare object cards (sun, wind, ocean, clock, stars, moon, river, mountain, fire, shadow). Mark examples of personification in previously read books.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the fun things we'll need for our personification mission! We've got a whiteboard and markers for writing, special "object cards" with things like the sun and the ocean on them, a journal for writing our own amazing sentences, and colored pencils for drawing. You'll also need some books that your teacher has already marked up with examples of personification.

slides.text: 'We know similes and metaphors. Today: PERSONIFICATION! This is when we give HUMAN qualities to non-human things. The wind does not really whisper — but when we say The wind whispered, we can almost HEAR it, can we not? We are treating the wind as if it were a person.'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, we already know about similes and metaphors, right? Well, today we're learning a new trick called personification! It's like pretending that things that aren't people, like the wind or a fluffy cloud, can act like people. For example, when we say "the wind whispered," we're pretending the wind has a mouth and can whisper secrets, just like you might!

slides.text: 'Listen for the human action in each example: The sun SMILED down on the village. Lightning DANCED across the sky. The flowers NODDED their heads. The ocean ROARED with anger. Can the sun really smile? Can flowers nod? No! But personification helps us FEEL the world around us as if nature were alive.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide gives us some super examples of personification in action! See how it says "The sun SMILED down"? The sun can't really smile, can it? But saying it smiled makes us feel warm and happy, like the sun is being friendly. We're going to look for those "human actions" in sentences to find the personification.

slides.text: 'You actually use personification all the time without knowing it! Have you ever said My computer is being stubborn or The alarm clock screamed at me? Those are personification! Let us play a game: I will hold up an object card, and you give it a human quality.' Practice with sun, wind, ocean, clock.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to play a game! This slide reminds us that we already use personification without even knowing it, like when you say your toy is "being stubborn." We're going to practice by looking at those object cards and thinking of a human thing each object could do, like maybe the clock is "running" fast when you're late!

slides.prompt: Write 8 personification sentences. Give human qualities to: the moon, the ocean, a mountain, time, a river, the wind, a shadow, and one object of your choice. Then choose your most vivid sentence and illustrate it literally — draw the object doing the human action!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the creator! Your job is to write eight sentences using personification, giving human actions to things like the moon or a river. Then, pick your very favorite sentence and draw a picture of it – imagine the moon *actually* winking at you!

slides.text: Personification brings the non-human world to life through language. When we say the wind whispered or the sun smiled, we help readers FEEL a connection to nature. You now know THREE types of figurative language: simile, metaphor, and personification. These are the tools that make writing magical!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify and write personification, distinguishing it from simile and metaphor?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! This slide is like our certificate of awesome. You've learned how personification makes writing come alive, like magic, and now you know three ways to make your writing sparkle: simile, metaphor, and personification! You're officially a figurative language superstar!

parent_notes: Personification is everywhere in everyday language: 'the car died,' 'my stomach is telling me,' 'the alarm screamed.' Help your child notice these expressions in conversation and books. The illustration activity (drawing a mountain literally marching or a clock literally running) creates memorable, often humorous images that cement the concept. Personification is also common in poetry — revisit some poems from last week to find examples.

title: Measurement — Capacity: Liters and Milliliters
description: Students learn to measure liquid capacity using liters (L) and milliliters (mL). They practice pouring, measuring with graduated cylinders, and understanding the relationship 1 L = 1,000 mL.
instructions:
1. Capacity: how much liquid a container can hold.
2. The liter (L): a common water bottle is 1 liter. Show one.
3. The milliliter (mL): a very small amount. 1 L = 1,000 mL. A teaspoon is about 5 mL.
4. Show measuring tools: measuring cups, graduated cylinders, marked pitchers.
5. Demonstrate reading a graduated cylinder: read at the bottom of the meniscus (curved surface).
6. Hands-on: pour water into containers and measure the volume.
7. Estimate and measure the capacity of various containers.
8. Conversion practice: 2 L = 2,000 mL; 3,500 mL = 3.5 L.
materials_needed: Graduated cylinders or measuring cups (mL and L)

slides.heading: Measurement
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our book! It tells us we're going to learn all about "Measurement," and specifically something called "Capacity," which is how much stuff, like water, can fit inside something. We'll be using two special words: Liters and Milliliters.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a water measurement station with towels to catch spills. Have containers of various sizes ready. Fill a large pitcher with water for pouring.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our super-duper measurement station ready! See those things on the list? We need the clear tubes with lines on them called graduated cylinders, or maybe some measuring cups. We'll also need water to measure, some different containers to fill up, and towels – just in case any water decides to go on an adventure! Grab all these things with a grown-up, and let's get ready to measure!

slides.text: 'We measured length and mass. Now we measure CAPACITY — how much liquid a container holds. The basic unit is the LITER.' Hold up a liter bottle. 'This is 1 liter. For smaller amounts, we use MILLILITERS. Milli means thousand, so 1 liter = 1,000 milliliters. A teaspoon is about 5 mL. A small medicine cup is about 30 mL.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is teaching us about "capacity." Think about a big soda bottle – it holds a lot of liquid, right? That "how much it holds" is its capacity! We use a big unit called a liter (L) for big amounts, like that water bottle you can buy at the store. For tiny amounts, like the medicine your grown-up might give you, we use a much smaller unit called a milliliter (mL). It takes a whopping 1,000 tiny milliliters to make just one big liter!

slides.text: 'To measure liquids, we use these tools.' Show graduated cylinder, measuring cups. 'Pour the liquid in and read the level. Important: read at the BOTTOM of the curved surface — this curve is called the meniscus. Always place the measuring tool on a flat surface and look at it at eye level.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to learn how to be super precise with our measuring! See these special tools, like the tall skinny tube with lines? When we pour liquid into them, the water makes a little curve at the top, called a meniscus. We always read the line at the *bottom* of that curve. Also, make sure your measuring tool is sitting perfectly flat on the table and you look at it right at your eye level, like you're a detective looking for clues!

slides.text: 'Let us practice! How much does this cup hold? Estimate first: I think about 250 mL. Now pour water in, measure, and check.' Demonstrate with 2-3 containers. 'Remember: 1,000 mL = 1 L. So 250 mL is one-quarter of a liter, or 0.25 L.' Connect to fractions and decimals.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the fun really begins – we get to practice! We'll pick a container, like a cup, and first guess how much water it can hold. Then, we'll carefully pour water into our measuring tool and see what the real number is! Remember, if you see 1,000 milliliters, that's the same as 1 whole liter. We'll even see how a number like 250 milliliters is just a little piece of a whole liter.

slides.prompt: Estimate and then measure the capacity of 6 containers. Record your estimate and actual measurement in mL. Convert each to liters. Then solve: A recipe calls for 750 mL of water. You have a 1 L bottle. How much water is left after pouring? If you need to double the recipe, how many mL total?
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to become measurement wizards! Your job is to look at six different containers, guess how much liquid each one can hold in milliliters, and then actually measure it to see if you were right. After that, you'll change those numbers into liters. You���ll also solve a couple of cool problems, like figuring out how much water is left in a bottle after you use some, and how much you'd need if you had to make a recipe twice!

slides.text: Capacity tells us how much liquid a container holds. We measure in liters (big amounts) and milliliters (small amounts). 1 L = 1,000 mL. Benchmarks: a water bottle is about 500 mL to 1 L, a teaspoon is about 5 mL, a bathtub is about 300 L. You now know three types of metric measurement: length, mass, AND capacity!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student measure liquid capacity in mL and L, read a graduated cylinder, and convert between units?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You learned all about capacity, which is how much liquid fits inside things. You practiced measuring with liters for big amounts and milliliters for small amounts, and you learned that 1,000 milliliters is the same as 1 liter. You're now a measurement expert in length, mass, *and* capacity – that’s three super important ways to understand the world!

parent_notes: Measuring capacity is naturally fun because it involves water and pouring. Cooking is the perfect real-world practice: recipes constantly use mL and L. Let your child measure ingredients for cooking. The connection to decimals and fractions is natural: 500 mL = 0.5 L = half a liter. The meniscus (curved water surface) is a good science observation too. Have towels ready — spills are part of learning!

title: Earth Science — Rocks and Minerals: The Three Types
description: Students begin earth science by learning about the three types of rocks: igneous (from fire/volcanoes), sedimentary (from layers of sediment), and metamorphic (changed by heat and pressure). They examine rock samples.
instructions:
1. Transition from living science to earth science: 'We studied animals. Now we study the Earth itself!'
2. What are rocks made of? Minerals — natural, non-living substances.
3. Three types of rocks:
   - IGNEOUS: formed from cooled lava/magma. Examples: granite, obsidian, basalt. 'Born from fire!'
   - SEDIMENTARY: formed from layers of sand, mud, shells compressed over millions of years. Examples: sandstone, limestone, shale.
   - METAMORPHIC: existing rocks changed by extreme heat and pressure. Examples: marble (from limestone), slate (from shale).
4. The rock cycle: rocks can change from one type to another over millions of years.
5. Examine rock samples with magnifying glasses.
6. Students create a rock cycle diagram.
materials_needed: Drawing paper for rock cycle diagram

slides.heading: Earth Science
slides.mascot_explanation: Hey there! This first slide is like the cover of our new science book. It tells us we're going to be learning all about rocks and minerals and how there are three main kinds. Get ready to become a rock expert!

slides.setup_instructions: Arrange rock samples by type. If real samples are unavailable, print high-quality images. Have magnifying glasses ready. Display a rock cycle poster.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our rock adventure! We've got different kinds of rocks to look at, magnifying glasses to see them up close like a detective, a special chart to help us figure out what each rock is, paper, and colored pencils for drawing. Ask a grown-up to help you gather all these supplies so we can get started!

slides.text: 'We have studied living things — animals and plants. Now we study the EARTH itself, starting with ROCKS! Rocks are everywhere: mountains, cliffs, riverbeds, even the ground beneath our feet. But not all rocks are the same. There are THREE main types, and each one forms in a different way.'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, we've learned about wiggly worms and tall trees, but now we're going to learn about something super old and strong: rocks! Rocks are all around us, from the giant mountains to the little pebbles in a stream. This slide is telling us that there are three special kinds of rocks, and each one is made in a totally different way.

slides.text: 'Type 1: IGNEOUS rocks form when hot melted rock (magma or lava) cools and hardens. Igneous means born from fire! When a volcano erupts, the lava cools and becomes rock. Granite, obsidian (volcanic glass), and basalt are all igneous.' Show samples. 'Type 2: SEDIMENTARY rocks form when layers of sand, mud, and shells pile up and get pressed together over millions of years. Sandstone, limestone, and shale are sedimentary. Fossils are found in these rocks!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is super neat! This slide introduces the first two types of rocks. Igneous rocks are like the "fire rocks" – they form when hot, melty stuff from inside the Earth cools down, like after a volcano erupts! Sedimentary rocks are made of tiny bits of sand, mud, and even shells that get squished together for a super, super long time, and sometimes you can even find fossils in them!

slides.text: 'Type 3: METAMORPHIC rocks start as one type but get CHANGED by extreme heat and pressure deep underground. Meta means change, morph means form. Limestone gets squeezed and heated into MARBLE. Shale becomes SLATE. The Parthenon in Athens was built from marble — a metamorphic rock! And these three types connect in a ROCK CYCLE: any rock can become any other type over millions of years.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for the third type of rock – metamorphic! These are rocks that started out as one kind but got changed by being squeezed and heated way down deep inside the Earth. Think of it like a rock getting a super-hot, super-squishy makeover! These three types of rocks are also part of a big circle called the rock cycle, where they can actually turn into each other over millions of years.

slides.prompt: Examine the rock samples with a magnifying glass. Classify each as igneous, sedimentary, or metamorphic. Record your observations (color, texture, crystals, layers). Then draw the ROCK CYCLE: show how igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks can transform into each other. Label the processes: melting, cooling, weathering, compacting, heat and pressure.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to be a rock scientist! Grab your magnifying glass and look super closely at each rock sample; see if you can spot any tiny crystals or layers. Then, use your chart to guess if it's igneous, sedimentary, or metamorphic, and write down what you see. After that, get your paper and colored pencils ready to draw the rock cycle, showing how rocks can change from one type to another!

slides.text: The three rock types tell the story of how the Earth works: volcanoes create igneous rock, erosion and time create sedimentary rock, and the immense forces underground create metamorphic rock. Rocks that look solid and permanent are actually always changing — just very, very slowly!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student name the three rock types, explain how each forms, and give examples of each?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You looked at rocks like a real scientist and learned about igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks, and how they all fit together in the amazing rock cycle. Isn't it cool that even though rocks seem so solid, they're actually changing all the time, just super, super slowly? You're a rock star!

parent_notes: Rock collecting is a wonderful hobby for children. Start a collection by finding rocks in your area and classifying them. Rock and mineral kits are available from educational suppliers and make this unit come alive. The rock cycle connects to many concepts: volcanoes, erosion, plate tectonics. The Parthenon being made of marble (metamorphic rock) connects nicely to the Greek history unit.

title: European Folk Music — Instruments and Traditions
description: Students explore the diverse folk music traditions of Europe, learning about instruments like the fiddle, accordion, bagpipes, and flamenco guitar. They listen to music from several European countries and compare styles.
instructions:
1. Europe has incredibly diverse music traditions — every country has its own folk music!
2. Listen to examples from 4-5 countries:
   - Ireland: fiddle and tin whistle (jigs and reels)
   - Spain: flamenco guitar and clapping
   - Scotland: bagpipes
   - Germany/Austria: accordion and yodeling
   - Greece: bouzouki and sirtaki dance music
3. Discuss: how does each style make you FEEL? Fast or slow? Happy or melancholy?
4. Identify common instruments: fiddle (violin played folk-style), accordion, bagpipes, guitar.
5. Try clapping along to different rhythms.
6. Students draw their favorite instrument and write about the music they liked best.
materials_needed: Audio recordings of European folk music (5 countries)

slides.heading: European Folk Music
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the cover of our exciting adventure! It tells us we're going to learn all about the special music from a big place called Europe, and the cool instruments people play there. It's going to be like a musical journey around the world!

slides.setup_instructions: Queue up 5 recordings (2-3 minutes each) from Ireland, Spain, Scotland, Germany, and Greece. Display instrument images and point to each country on the map as its music plays.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our explorer gear ready! We need to find the audio recordings – those are like little sound stories from different countries. We also need pictures of the instruments, paper and pencils for drawing later, and a map so we can see where we're "traveling" in Europe. Go grab those with a grown-up!

slides.text: 'Europe has some of the most diverse and beautiful folk music in the world. Every country — sometimes every region within a country — has its own unique style. Today we take a musical tour of Europe!' Point to each country on the map as you introduce its music.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our starting point for our European music trip! It's telling us that Europe has tons of different kinds of music, and each country has its own special sounds, just like how different families have their own traditions. We're going to listen to music from five different places and see how unique they are.

slides.text: Play each recording, one at a time. 'This is Irish music — hear the fast fiddle and tin whistle? People dance jigs to this! Now Spain — flamenco has passionate guitar, hand clapping, and rhythmic stomping. Scotland — the BAGPIPES! Made from a bag that pushes air through pipes. Germany — the accordion, often with yodeling! And Greece — the bouzouki, with the famous sirtaki dance.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to listen to some amazing sounds! We'll hear music from Ireland with a fast fiddle, Spain with a special guitar and clapping, Scotland with the loud bagpipes, Germany with an accordion and singing, and Greece with music for dancing. Each one is super different and tells a story about its country.

slides.text: 'How does each style make you FEEL? Irish jigs might make you want to dance. Flamenco might feel fiery and passionate. Bagpipes might sound powerful and stirring. Music reflects the spirit of a culture. Let us clap along to each rhythm.' Practice clapping different rhythms.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to think about how the music makes us feel! Does it make you want to jump up and dance, or maybe feel a little calm? We'll also practice clapping along to the different beats, like playing our own rhythm instruments with our hands.

slides.prompt: Draw your favorite European folk instrument in detail. Write: what country is it from, what does it sound like (use descriptive words), and how did the music make you feel? Then rank the 5 music styles from your most to least favorite and explain why.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the artist and writer! Pick your favorite instrument from all the music we heard, draw a picture of it, and write down what country it's from, what it sounds like, and how the music made you feel. Then, tell us which music you liked the best and why!

slides.text: European folk music shows how the same basic human desire to make music leads to incredibly different results depending on culture and geography. Irish jigs, Spanish flamenco, Scottish bagpipes, German polkas, and Greek dance music are all expressions of joy, sorrow, celebration, and tradition.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify folk music styles and instruments from at least 3 European countries?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we just learned about so many cool European folk music styles and instruments! You discovered how music can sound so different but still be special to each place, like Irish jigs or Scottish bagpipes. You've really become a European music expert!

parent_notes: Music is one of the best windows into a culture. After this lesson, explore more European folk music on YouTube or streaming services. Many children develop strong preferences and want to learn more about specific traditions. If you can attend a folk music performance or festival, the experience is unforgettable. Playing recordings during dinner and asking 'What country do you think this is from?' extends the learning.

title: Care of the Environment — Plant Care and Gardening
description: Students learn to care for indoor plants and prepare a simple container garden. They practice watering techniques, soil preparation, and seed planting, connecting to botany knowledge.
instructions:
1. Connect to botany: 'We studied plants — roots, stems, leaves, flowers. Now we GROW them!'
2. Discuss what plants need: sunlight, water, soil (nutrients), air, space.
3. Demonstrate proper watering: check soil moisture first (stick finger in soil), water at the base not on leaves, do not overwater.
4. Prepare containers: add drainage material (pebbles), potting soil, create a small hole.
5. Plant seeds or seedlings: cover seeds lightly, press soil gently, water.
6. Label plants with name and planting date.
7. Create a care schedule: how often to water, where to place for sunlight.
8. Clean up the workspace.
materials_needed: Seeds (fast-growing: beans, herbs, marigolds) or seedlings

slides.heading: Practical Life
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our exciting gardening book! It tells us we're going to learn all about taking care of plants and even growing our own, which is called "Plant Care and Gardening." Isn't it cool that we can grow things right in our classroom or home?

slides.setup_instructions: Cover the workspace with newspaper. Pre-fill a tray with potting soil. Have pots, pebbles, seeds, and watering can arranged neatly.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, look at all these things we need for our gardening adventure! We have little pots to plant in, special dirt called potting soil, tiny seeds or baby plants called seedlings, small rocks called pebbles, a watering can for our plants, and markers and labels to name our plants. Don't forget the newspaper to keep our workspace tidy! Ask a grown-up to help you gather everything.

slides.text: 'We studied plants in science — now we get to GROW them! Caring for plants teaches patience, responsibility, and observation. Remember what plants need: water, sunlight, soil with nutrients, and air. Today we will plant seeds and learn how to care for them.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we learned all about the parts of a plant, like roots, stems, and leaves? Well, now we get to be plant growers and help them grow big and strong! This step reminds us that plants need sunshine, water, good soil, and fresh air, just like we do, and taking care of them teaches us to be patient and observant.

slides.text: 'First: prepare the pot. Add a layer of small pebbles at the bottom for drainage — this lets extra water escape so the roots do not drown. Then fill with potting soil, leaving about an inch at the top.' Demonstrate. 'Now make a small hole with your finger, drop in 2-3 seeds, and cover lightly with soil. Press gently. Water carefully — not too much!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to get our pots ready! First, we put some pebbles at the bottom – these help extra water drain out so the plant's roots don't get soggy and sad. Then, we fill the pot with soil, leaving a little space at the top, and poke a small hole to tuck in 2 or 3 seeds, covering them gently with more soil. Finally, we give them a little drink of water, but not too much!

slides.text: 'Caring for plants is an ongoing responsibility. Check the soil every day: if the top feels dry, water it. Place your plant near a window for sunlight. Talk to your plant — some people believe it helps! Label your pot with the plant name and today's date, so you can track how long it takes to sprout.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Taking care of our plants is like having a little pet that needs us every day! We need to check the soil to see if it feels dry – if it does, it's time for a drink. We'll also find a sunny spot for our plant because they love soaking up the sun's rays. And don't forget to write your plant's name and the date you planted it on the label so we can watch it grow!

slides.prompt: Plant your own container garden: prepare the pot with drainage and soil, plant your seeds, water carefully, and label. Create a care schedule card: plant name, light needs, watering frequency, expected sprout time. Set up your plant in a good location and clean up your workspace completely.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the super gardener! You’ll get to prepare a pot with pebbles and soil, carefully plant your seeds, give them a gentle watering, and label your creation. Then, you'll make a special card that tells you exactly how much sun and water your plant needs and when you might see it sprout, and after you set up your plant in its sunny spot, you'll clean up your whole area.

slides.text: You are now responsible for a living thing! Check your plant daily, water when needed, and observe any changes. Keep a growth journal — measure and sketch your plant each week. Gardening teaches us that good things take time, care, and patience.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student properly plant seeds, describe plant care requirements, and create a care schedule?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at what you've accomplished – you've planted your very own garden and made a special plan to care for it! You are now in charge of a living thing, and by checking on it every day and giving it what it needs, you'll see it grow. This teaches us that with a little bit of time and lots of patience, amazing things can happen!

parent_notes: Gardening is one of the most rewarding practical life activities. Fast-growing plants like beans or radishes show results within a week, maintaining motivation. Herbs (basil, cilantro, parsley) are practical because the child can eventually use them in cooking. Keep a growth journal — measuring the plant weekly connects to math measurement skills. This activity teaches responsibility, patience, and nurturing — core Montessori values.

title: Figurative Language — Reading Comprehension with Figurative Language
description: Students practice identifying and interpreting all three types of figurative language (simile, metaphor, personification) in the context of real passages. They determine literal vs. figurative meaning.
instructions:
1. Review all three types: simile (like/as), metaphor (is), personification (human qualities to non-human).
2. Read a short passage together. Stop at each figurative language example.
3. For each example: identify the type, explain what it literally says vs. what it actually means.
4. Discuss: why did the author choose figurative language instead of literal? What effect does it create?
5. Practice with 3 passages, increasing independence.
6. Students highlight/circle figurative language in a passage and label each instance.
7. Rewrite figurative sentences in literal language and compare the effect.
materials_needed: Highlighters (3 colors: one for each type)

slides.heading: Figurative Language
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure today! It tells us we're going to be exploring something super cool called "Figurative Language," and we'll be using it to become even better readers. Think of it like unlocking a secret code that authors use to make their stories extra exciting!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 3 short passages rich in figurative language. Print copies for highlighting. Create a color code: yellow = simile, blue = metaphor, green = personification.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the tools we'll need for our reading mission. We've got our reading passages, which are like treasure maps filled with interesting words. Then, we have three different colored highlighters – yellow is for similes, blue is for metaphors, and green is for personification, so we can color-code our discoveries. We also need our writing journal and pencils to jot down our thoughts, and a reference chart that will be like our cheat sheet for remembering the different types of figurative language. Make sure you have all these things ready to go with a grown-up's help!

slides.text: 'This week we learned similes, metaphors, and personification. Today we practice FINDING them in real reading passages. Good readers notice figurative language because it is key to understanding what an author really means. The wind howled does not mean the wind is literally a wolf!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about remembering what we've learned. We're going to be like detectives today, looking for similes (words that use "like" or "as"), metaphors (words that say something *is* something else), and personification (giving human feelings or actions to things that aren't human). It's important because authors use these tricks to make their writing pop and to help us understand their ideas in a more interesting way, not just plain old facts!

slides.text: Read the first passage together. Stop at each figurative expression. 'Her smile was as warm as sunshine — what type? Simile! What does it mean literally? Her smile made people feel good, like standing in warm sunlight. Why did the author write it this way instead of just saying She had a nice smile? Because the simile creates a FEELING.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we get to practice what we learned! We'll read the first passage together, and when we find a special phrase, we'll stop and figure it out. For example, if it says "Her smile was as warm as sunshine," we'll say "That's a simile!" Then, we'll think about what it *really* means – her smile made people feel happy and comfortable, just like sunshine feels warm. We'll talk about why the author didn't just say "She had a nice smile" but chose to make it more exciting!

slides.text: 'Let us try something interesting: rewrite figurative language as literal language. The mountain stood guard over the valley becomes The mountain was next to the valley. Which one paints a better picture? The figurative version! That is WHY authors use figurative language — to make writing vivid and memorable.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super fun part where we get to play with words! We'll take a sentence that uses figurative language, like "The mountain stood guard over the valley," and change it into a plain, literal sentence, like "The mountain was next to the valley." Then, we'll decide which sentence makes us feel more and helps us imagine the scene better – usually, the figurative one is way more exciting, right? This shows us why authors love using figurative language so much!

slides.prompt: Read the passages and highlight figurative language in 3 colors: yellow = simile, blue = metaphor, green = personification. Label each example. Then choose 3 figurative sentences and rewrite them in literal language. Compare: which version is more interesting? Write a short paragraph explaining why authors use figurative language.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time for you to be the star! You'll read the next passages and use your yellow highlighter for similes, blue for metaphors, and green for personification, just like we planned. After you highlight, you'll write down what each one means literally. Then, pick three sentences and rewrite them without figurative language, and write a little bit about why authors choose to write in such cool, imaginative ways. You have 20 minutes to show off your amazing skills!

slides.text: Figurative language is a powerful reading comprehension tool. When you read the mountain stood guard, you understand more than just location — you understand that the mountain feels protective and strong. From now on, look for figurative language in everything you read. It will deepen your understanding and make you a better writer too!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify similes, metaphors, and personification in context and explain their literal vs. figurative meanings?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You've become a fantastic detective of figurative language. You learned how to spot similes, metaphors, and personification and understand what they really mean, making stories much more exciting. Remember how we saw that "the mountain stood guard" made it sound strong and protective? Keep looking for these word tricks everywhere you read; it's going to make you an even stronger reader and a super creative writer!

parent_notes: Figurative language comprehension is a critical reading skill tested on standardized assessments. More importantly, it deepens understanding and appreciation of literature. After this lesson, when you read together, pause occasionally and ask: 'Is the author being literal or figurative? What does that really mean?' This develops analytical reading habits that will serve your child throughout their education.

title: Measurement — Comparing and Converting Mass and Capacity
description: Students practice converting between grams/kilograms and milliliters/liters, and solve comparison and word problems involving both types of measurement.
instructions:
1. Review: 1 kg = 1,000 g, 1 L = 1,000 mL. Both use the same kilo/milli pattern!
2. Side-by-side conversions: mass and capacity follow the same rules.
3. Comparison problems: which is more, 2 kg or 1,500 g? 3 L or 3,200 mL?
4. Word problems mixing mass and capacity:
   - 'A recipe needs 500 g of flour and 250 mL of milk. If you double the recipe, how much of each?'
   - 'A bottle holds 2 L. You pour out 750 mL. How much is left?'
5. Connect to decimals: 1,500 g = 1.5 kg; 250 mL = 0.25 L.
6. Challenge: ordering items by mass or capacity from least to greatest.
materials_needed: Balance scale and measuring cups (for verification)

slides.heading: Measurement
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of our adventure! It's telling us we're going to become super-smart at measuring two important things: how heavy stuff is (that's mass) and how much stuff a container can hold (that's capacity). Think about how you measure your toys to see which is heavier or how much juice fits in a cup – that's what we're learning about today!

slides.setup_instructions: Create a reference chart showing the parallel structure: 1 km = 1000 m, 1 kg = 1000 g, 1 L = 1000 mL. Prepare word problems of increasing difficulty.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's gather our tools for this mission! We've got a conversion chart that's like a secret codebook for measurements, a whiteboard to practice writing things down, and a worksheet with problems to solve. We'll also need pencils to write, and a scale to weigh things and measuring cups to see how much liquid fits inside. Make sure you have a grown-up with you to help get these things ready!

slides.text: 'Great news: mass and capacity conversions work EXACTLY like length conversions! 1 kg = 1,000 g, just like 1 km = 1,000 m. 1 L = 1,000 mL, same pattern. The metric system is beautifully consistent — everything is based on powers of 10.' Show the parallel conversion chart.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is super cool because it tells us the metric system is like a big family where everyone follows the same rules! Just like 1 kilometer is 1,000 meters, 1 kilogram is also 1,000 grams, and 1 liter is 1,000 milliliters. See that pattern? It means if you know how to switch between kilometers and meters, you already know how to switch between kilograms and grams, and liters and milliliters!

slides.text: 'Which is heavier: 2 kg or 1,500 g? Let us convert to the same unit. 2 kg = 2,000 g. Now compare: 2,000 g > 1,500 g. So 2 kg is heavier. Which holds more: 3 L or 3,200 mL? 3 L = 3,000 mL. 3,200 > 3,000, so 3,200 mL is more.' Practice comparing 3 more pairs.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to be detectives and figure out which is more! For example, if we have 2 kilograms of apples and someone else has 1,500 grams, we need to change them to the same measuring unit to compare. Since 1 kilogram is 1,000 grams, 2 kilograms is the same as 2,000 grams, which is more than 1,500 grams! We'll do this for a few more pairs to get really good at comparing.

slides.text: 'Word problem: A recipe needs 500 g of flour and 250 mL of milk. If you triple the recipe, how much of each? Flour: 500 x 3 = 1,500 g = 1.5 kg. Milk: 250 x 3 = 750 mL = 0.75 L. See how decimals help us express these conversions neatly?' Solve together.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like solving a puzzle from a story! Imagine a recipe needs flour and milk. If we want to make *triple* the amount, we need to figure out how much flour and milk we'll need. We'll take the original amounts and multiply them by three, and then we can even write those big numbers as smaller decimal numbers, like 1.5 kilograms or 0.75 liters, which is a neat trick!

slides.prompt: Solve: (1) 3 kg = ? g, (2) 4,500 g = ? kg, (3) 2 L = ? mL, (4) 750 mL = ? L, (5) Which is more: 1.5 kg or 1,200 g? (6) Which is more: 0.5 L or 600 mL? Word problems: A watermelon has a mass of 3.5 kg. You cut off a 900 g slice. How much is left (in kg)?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to put your detective skills to the test with some practice problems! You'll get to do some conversions yourself, like changing kilograms to grams or liters to milliliters, and then compare some amounts to see which is bigger. There's even a word problem about a watermelon where you'll need to figure out how much is left after a slice is taken. You've got this!

slides.text: The metric system makes conversions easy because the same pattern repeats: kilo means 1,000, milli means 1/1,000. Length (km, m, cm, mm), mass (kg, g, mg), and capacity (L, mL) all work the same way. You are now a metric measurement expert!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student convert between grams/kilograms and milliliters/liters and solve comparison word problems?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you've just become a measurement master! We learned that the "kilo" part of words like kilogram and kilometer means 1,000, and the "milli" part means a tiny fraction. This pattern works for measuring how long things are, how heavy they are, and how much they can hold, which is amazing! You can now compare and change between grams and kilograms, and milliliters and liters like a pro!

parent_notes: The parallel structure of metric units is the key insight: kilo always means 1,000 and milli always means 1/1,000, regardless of whether you are measuring length, mass, or capacity. Cooking is the best practice: recipes use grams and milliliters constantly. Let your child measure ingredients independently. The decimal connection (1,500 g = 1.5 kg) reinforces earlier decimal work.

title: Ancient Greece — Alexander the Great
description: Students learn about Alexander the Great: his education by Aristotle, his conquest of the Persian Empire, and how he spread Greek culture across a vast territory (Hellenistic period).
instructions:
1. Connect to philosophers: 'Remember Aristotle? His most famous student was not a philosopher but a king — Alexander of Macedonia!'
2. Alexander became king at age 20 after his father Philip II was assassinated.
3. He conquered the Persian Empire, Egypt, and lands as far as India — all by age 30!
4. He founded cities named Alexandria (the most famous in Egypt had the Great Library).
5. He spread Greek language, culture, and ideas everywhere he went — this is called Hellenization.
6. He died at only 32 — one of history's greatest 'what ifs.'
7. Show his empire on a map. Students trace the route of his conquests and label key cities.

slides.heading: Ancient Greece
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is the title of our lesson! It tells us we're going to learn all about a super famous guy from ancient times named Alexander the Great, and how he was connected to ancient Greece. It’s like the cover of a really exciting book!

slides.setup_instructions: Print a map showing Alexander's empire from Greece to India. Have the timeline updated with philosophers. Print blank outline maps of the same region.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our activity. We've got a map to look at, a timeline to see when things happened, a blank map for us to draw on, and colorful pencils to make our maps awesome. You'll need to grab these with a grown-up's help so we can get started on our adventure!

slides.text: 'Aristotle's most famous student was not a philosopher — he was a CONQUEROR. His name was Alexander, and the world called him Alexander the GREAT. He was prince of Macedonia, a kingdom just north of Greece. His father, King Philip, hired Aristotle himself to tutor young Alexander. Imagine having one of the greatest minds in history as your personal teacher!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part tells us about Alexander's amazing teacher, Aristotle! Remember how we learned about philosophers? Well, Aristotle was one of the most famous ones, and he taught Alexander, who became a super powerful king instead of a philosopher. It's pretty neat that such a smart teacher helped train a great leader, right?

slides.text: 'When Alexander became king at age 20, he set out to conquer the world — and he nearly did! He defeated the mighty Persian Empire, conquered Egypt (where he founded the city of ALEXANDRIA and its legendary Great Library), and pushed east all the way to INDIA! All of this before he turned 31. His empire stretched from Greece to the borders of China.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, get a load of this! This slide shows how Alexander became king when he was super young, only 20 years old, and then he went on to conquer HUGE amounts of land, like the Persian Empire and even Egypt, all before he was 31! He even started a city called Alexandria that had a giant library, which is like the biggest library ever!

slides.text: 'Wherever Alexander went, he brought Greek language, art, architecture, and ideas. This mixing of Greek culture with Eastern cultures is called HELLENIZATION — spreading all things Greek. Greek became the common language of trade and learning across a huge area. Sadly, Alexander died at only 32, possibly from disease. His empire was divided among his generals. But Greek culture remained!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This tells us about something called "Hellenization," which is a big word, but it just means Alexander spread Greek culture – like their language, art, and ideas – everywhere his empire reached. Think about how your favorite games or cartoons might be popular all over the world; it was kind of like that, but with ancient Greek stuff!

slides.prompt: On your outline map, trace Alexander's route of conquest from Macedonia through Turkey, Egypt, Persia, and to India. Label: Macedonia, Athens, Alexandria (Egypt), Babylon, Persepolis, and the Indus River. Color the extent of his empire. Write 3 sentences about why he is called 'the Great.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it’s your turn to be the explorer! This slide is asking you to use your map and colored pencils to draw the path Alexander took when he conquered all those places, all the way from where he started to India. You'll also get to label important cities and rivers, and then write a few sentences about why everyone called him "the Great." You've got this!

slides.text: Alexander the Great conquered more territory in 11 years than anyone before him. But his greatest legacy was not military — it was cultural. By spreading Greek language and ideas across three continents, he created a shared culture that lasted for centuries and influenced everything that came after, including Rome.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe Alexander's major achievements, trace his route of conquest, and explain Hellenization?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the end of our lesson, and it's telling us that Alexander was amazing not just because he conquered so much land, but because he spread Greek culture everywhere. This sharing of ideas helped shape other big empires, like Rome, and it shows how one person can really change the world! You did a great job following his journey!

parent_notes: Alexander the Great is one of history's most fascinating figures. The fact that he accomplished so much so young captivates children. The connection to Aristotle shows how education shapes destiny. The Great Library of Alexandria is particularly exciting — it was an attempt to collect ALL human knowledge in one place. Discuss: what would a modern Library of Alexandria look like? (Perhaps the internet!) Alexander's story also leads naturally into the next civilization: Rome.

title: The Legacy of Greece — Greek Words in English
description: Students explore the extensive influence of Greek language on modern English. They learn common Greek roots, prefixes, and suffixes and use them to decode unfamiliar words.
instructions:
1. Review roots from last week: tele, graph, bio, geo, phon, scope.
2. Add new roots: auto (self), micro (small), mega (large/great), chrono (time), astro (star), hydro (water).
3. Add prefixes: anti- (against), mono- (one), poly- (many), hyper- (over/excessive).
4. Word building game: combine roots to make real words. Auto + graph = autograph (self-writing = signature!).
5. Decode unfamiliar words: chronometer (time measurer = clock), microscope (small viewer), polyglot (many tongues = speaks many languages).
6. Students create a Greek Root Dictionary: 10+ entries with root, meaning, and example words.
7. Challenge: can you figure out what 'autobiography' means using roots alone?

slides.heading: Legacy of Greece
slides.mascot_explanation: Hey there! This first slide is like the cover page for our adventure today. It's telling us that we're going to learn all about how the ancient Greeks, way back in time, gave us so many words that we still use in English today. Isn't it cool that words can travel through history like that?

slides.setup_instructions: Make root word cards with the Greek root on one side and meaning on the other. Prepare blank booklets for the dictionary. Have a comprehensive root list available.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the super cool tools we'll need for our Greek word mission! We've got these "Greek root cards" that are like secret code cards – one side has a Greek word part, and the other has what it means. We also have a blank booklet for our very own dictionary, pencils for writing, a whiteboard to draw on, and a list that has all the Greek roots we might need. You'll need to gather these up so we're ready to go!

slides.text: 'Last week we learned some Greek roots: tele (far), graph (write), bio (life). Today we add more! AUTO means self — an automobile moves by itself! MICRO means small, MEGA means great. CHRONO means time — a chronometer measures time. ASTRO means star — an astronaut is a star sailor! HYDRO means water — a hydrant shoots water.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we get to add some awesome new Greek word parts to our collection! Remember from last week "tele" means far, like a telephone? Well, today we're learning "auto" which means self, like how a car drives by itself. We're also learning "micro" for small, "mega" for big, "chrono" for time (like a clock!), "astro" for stars, and "hydro" for water. Keep these meanings in your brain like little treasures!

slides.text: 'Now the magic: COMBINE roots to decode words you have never seen before! MICRO + SCOPE = microscope: a tool for seeing small things. TELE + SCOPE = telescope: a tool for seeing far things. AUTO + BIO + GRAPH + Y = autobiography: writing about your own life. You can figure out the meaning from the parts!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the really fun part – putting the word parts together like building blocks! See how "micro" means small and "scope" means to look? When you put them together, "microscope" means something that lets you look at tiny things you can't see normally. We can even figure out "autobiography" by looking at "auto" (self) and "bio" (life) and "graph" (write) – it means writing about your own life!

slides.text: 'Let us try some hard ones: CHRONOLOGY = chrono (time) + logy (study of) = the study of time order. POLYTHEISM = poly (many) + theos (god) + ism = belief in many gods — that is what the Greeks had! DEMOCRACY = demos (people) + kratos (rule) = rule by the people!' Build on the board.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we're learning some big words today, but with our Greek roots, they're not so scary! Take "chronology" – we know "chrono" means time, and "logy" means study, so it's the study of time! The Greeks also believed in "polytheism," and we know "poly" means many, so that's believing in many gods. And "democracy"?
